comments.commentBody:
My child is in kindergarten this year and we don't know very many parents at the school, so I had to wing it...
I purchased a gift card for the teacher ($40, though I paid less) that I wrapped up with a favorite children's book. I went with gourmet treats for the "other" teachers—gym, art, music etc—that could easily be re-gifted. Plus small gifts for the school secretary and the principal, who has gone out of her way for us this fall.
After reading this, I'm feeling some guilt that everything is store-bought. But if I were a teacher? I think I'd prefer the gift card to the flaxseed blueberry bread, however nice the gesture.
And we are not trying to buy favors or grades, just saying thanks.

Here's what I recommend: don't worry about the teacher during the holiday season. Instead, put a reminder on your calendar for March 1, 2012. When March comes around write her a lovely thank-you note and enclose a gift card to an arts and crafts store.

Everyone gets gifts in December, and teachers have a holiday break to look forward to as well. March, though, is another story. Here in Ohio, it's muddy and cold, and warmth and spring flowers are still a month away. The school supplies from September are a distant memory, and the supplies given as gifts in December are starting to run out.

Your child's teacher gets lots of gifts and notes in December, but your will be the only one she gets in March.
Whoops, meant to write "near the end of each semester".

In my teaching experience, the gift cards and trinkets are nice, but the best gifts, hands down, are the handwritten notes from my students saying thank you for teaching them and happy holidays. I enjoy hearing from students in their own words, and the best part is not having to write thank you notes back!
What a great idea!

What about a nice, high quality candle? I love candles and you use them up so they don't just pile up over the years. They're not that expensive, but are festive, unisex, non-denominational, won't make them fat if they're watching the snacks, are gifty (non-utilitarian).
I bet the teachers in my district would read what you wrote and say "Please NO! The LAST thing we need is one more ounce of involvement from the parents here."
As a previous poster said, nice in theory, yucky in practice. The two teachers I know personally dump this stuff before they leave school. They see where little hands go and ewWWWWW!
I want to be a student in your classroom.  :)

Thanks for linking to Edutopia's latest gift guide for teachers. One quick correction: You're currently linking to one of the forums we used to crowdsource some information. Our latest 2011 Gift Guide for teachers can be found here: http://www.edutopia.org/holiday-gift-guide-teachers-2011. The top responses include: simple thank-you's, gift certificates, classroom supplies, iPads or Kindles, something homemade, and more.

Hope this is useful,
Elana Leoni
Social Media Marketing Manager | Edutopia.org

I don't like the idea of the coupon for 1 hour of the kids' undivided attention ... The kids should be paying attention all the time, hello.

When no one's organizing a group thing, I usually give gift cards or small boxes of candies, things a teacher can use and then they're gone. I don't want to give them clutter.

One thought: a small private school my kids attended until recently would collect donations (voluntary) from the parents, pool it and divide it equally among all the teachers. That way, people like the janitors wouldn't be forgotten. And one teacher wouldn't get much more than another simply because he or she had the kids from the wealthiest families that year.

In another school, when the class mother collected donations, she emphasized that, whether or not the parents donated, all kids would sign the card to the teacher.

A friend whose parents are from Korea said that they always gave extravagent gifts to his teachers, the most expensive ones they bought for anybody. It was a cultural thing. (Also, if he did something wrong at home, his mother would threaten to tell his teacher.)

The more one hears Newt Gingrich talk, the more one senses the vernacular of a Washington politician. It is defensive, self-aggrandizing...sometimes condescending, to the point of arrogrance.

It is based on the fact of immunity from criticism. A fact that has evolved as the length of service of the politicians tenure in Washington. Do not criticize me...Washingtons reply to those that would.

It is common to hear a politician in Washington, when questioned on a particular issue, talk around the question...or to blame others for a problem...at no time will one hear a poitician saying he was wrong and the opposition was right.

Such is a man...Newt Gingrich.

It is as if the Obama Administration has caused so much damage to the publics' opinion of Washington, that now they would revert back to the days of the Gingrich ploys in Congress. Now, Gingrich in his way of spouting his accomplishments back then...it was in 1974, more than 30 years ago, Gingrich bragged that they were working on a health care reform bill. We know what happened to that...nothing.

It is now that Gingrich and others pile on Romney for his attempt to fix the Massachusetts health care problem; yet Gingrich, the visionary failed back in 1974 when it was an issue. Gingrich would respond...it was others that failed.

Word is, some feel gridlock started with the Gingrich days in Congress, now growing worse. To send Gingrich back to Washington as president of the United States is insane and fundamentally wrong.

I've been to school board meetings - it's a pittance what teachers (especially young ones) make compared to most professionals-knowing that my own income is probably higher than deserved (I'm not a primary care doc), I always give to the group gift and will try to send a small something individually, especially for the favorite teachers (what's wrong with rewarding excellence?!). the group gift is nice in that, for the families hit by unemployment or other stressors, they're covered by the group - there's no card with only some names on it-it's from ALL. this is a well-to-do private school but, given the cost of housing, I think the public schools are similar. Thinking back to my grade school in a middle class neighborhood, and, at least until 6th grade, when I had one classroom teacher, my mother always got a small gift for the teacher (this is back in the 1970's) - it was often chocolate or candies -as gift cards weren't as common back then -but I think it's always been considered a way to show appreciation.
The teachers are asking for gifts.  We give them gifts because we appreciate the long hours they put in working with our kids.
Sorry, teachers AREN'T asking for gifts.

I just watched this debate on C-SPAN and enjoyed every minute, finally an intelligent discussion about events and issues facing the country. It matters not to me if they be Republicans, Democrats, or Independents, it's the only way to understand who these people are and what they believe.

Both of them were terrific!

It should be mandatory for all presidential elections.
Scoring political points at the expense of the country is one of the few things Republicans do well.

The only  hope for humanity is to drop the pessimism and derision and work together to end the ignorance of how we're rapidly making the world unfit for the survival of our species. I happen to agree with you on the energy, but washing your hands of the whole lot of us doesn't do much good. Drop the cynacism and try to do something about it.

"I have a bachelors in science and I love articles like this. "

Articles like this are written for you and believers in the god particle. Pure nonsense....
I am so thrilled to finally find a comment from Michigan that is not so stupid it embarrasses me!

I have a bachelors in science and I love articles like this. If you can't understand and it makes your brain hurt then don't read it and don't bother commenting. The only hope for humanity is to understand our natural world. We need clean limitless energy and the only hope is to fully understand physics so we will stop buring stuff. Fusion power is our only salvation, you look at it every day when the sun rises in the east. To harness fusion we probably need to understand gravity. We need to spend a whole lot more on basic science and spend less on war and politics. I have zero hope this will happen so good day.

EXACTLY. When are people going to realize that the deeper you dig, the further from the truth you really are?

We as humans and "thinkers" can't stand the notion that we may never know everything about the universe and why it is the way it is. If we accepted this cold hard reality, we'd be much better off in the long run.

Tried reading Lisa Randall's Warped Passages. Gave up. Her writing is too dense. Does not write well for the lay public. Try Leonard Susskind and Brian Greene. Particularly Greene's latest and best The Hidden Reality. Greene tells it like it is. The cutting edge raises more questions than answers.

All this is way beyond my 50 plus year old knowledge. Good questions, Mr. Overbye, One thing I understand: a possible delay of Higgs mechanism/boson discrovery because of cancellation of the US supercollider.

That is not a difficult scientific concept, just politics. As a former scientist I understand the 'urgency' to solve major problems in all scientific fields. A balance, however, has to be maintained. Currently I do not see any truly urgent issues that had to be solved as soon as possible (in basic science, applied sciences like medicine are something else).

There is plenty of time to clarify the issue of Higgs mechanism and boson. Similarly, there is plenty of time to travel to Mars and beyond - our Sun is going to be a good neighbor for several billions of years. Not likely that the fundamental laws of physic will (the objective ones, not our interpretaions, of course) will change during that time either.

So, dear particle scientists, take it easy and take your time.
You are right. I don't know why these guys don't read the bible for once, everything is written in it. In God we trust.
Well said!  How can we all get some of that Georgia wine?

Not by any stretch the Times' finest hour covering the GOP race.  But political coverage has long devolved into a poll-driven horse race, where issues and the candidates' mental and moral capacity to be President are barely mentioned, much less covered.

After sitting down to watch the debate over a glass of wine I have to say (as an Obama liberal) I enjoyed it, and I was dismayed to read such a snarky, jaded nytimes review. Sure, I expected sarcastic reviews by bloggers and on twitter, but I would expect that at very least the voice of record would stand on the side of the candidates themselves and agree that in an hour and twenty minutes the event did far more good for our democracy than hour after hour of gotcha debates on cable television have done in the past six months. The black coffee joke was especially ill taken, as well as the graduate seminar reference - do you really think so little of Americans? Then perhaps you, and not they, are the problem. At a time when we hear coffeeshop liberals complain about the lack of substantial debate in politics, to see such a heaping offering be received with a cynical yawn by the New York Times is the point where I start to side with conservatives when they complain about the spineless hypocrisy of urban liberal types.
I think that the term 'charge' is meant figuratevly, not literrally as an electric charge (in coulombs).

What does Gingrich think we've been doing to Iran up to now? We're already waging a nearly hot war against them, and certainly a full-fledged diplomatic and political war. This is very unserious rhetoric on his part.
They know as much as the can and some of them are actually not geeks. Otherwise we have to be bit thrifty in building their super-toys. See my comment (if published).
